Question: Find all numbers that appear in each of a set of lists: :I have several ArrayLists of Integer objects, stored in a HashMap.I want to get a list (ArrayList) of all the numbers (Integer objects) that appear in each list.My thinking so far is:Iterate through each ArrayList and put all the values into a HashSet This will give us a "listing" of all the values in the lists, but only onceIterate through the HashSet 2.1 With each iteration perform ArrayList.contains()  2.2 If none of the ArrayLists return false for the operation add the number to a "master list" which contains all the final values.If you can come up with something faster or more efficient, funny thing is as I wrote this I came up with a reasonably good solution. But I'll still post it just in case it is useful for someone else.But of course if you have a better way please do let me know.
Please using this api: Iterator.next.
Answer:
response:
Please answer my code questions using the given API following this format: <<<api>>>: $API
<<<code>>>: $CODE
<<<explanation>>>: $EXPLANATION.
Question: Find all numbers that appear in each of a set of lists: :I have several ArrayLists of Integer objects, stored in a HashMap.I want to get a list (ArrayList) of all the numbers (Integer objects) that appear in each list.My thinking so far is:Iterate through each ArrayList and put all the values into a HashSet This will give us a "listing" of all the values in the lists, but only onceIterate through the HashSet 2.1 With each iteration perform ArrayList.contains()  2.2 If none of the ArrayLists return false for the operation add the number to a "master list" which contains all the final values.If you can come up with something faster or more efficient, funny thing is as I wrote this I came up with a reasonably good solution. But I'll still post it just in case it is useful for someone else.But of course if you have a better way please do let me know.
Please using this api: Iterator.next.
Answer:
<<<api>>>: Iterator.next
<<<code>>>: 
```java
HashMap<String, ArrayList<Integer>> map = new HashMap<>();
// populate map

ArrayList<Integer> masterList = new ArrayList<>();
Iterator<ArrayList<Integer>> it = map.values().iterator();
if (it.hasNext()) {
    ArrayList<Integer> firstList = it.next();
    for (Integer i : firstList) {
        if (allListsContain(i, map.values())) {
            masterList.add(i);
        }
    }
}

private boolean allListsContain(Integer i, Collection<ArrayList<Integer>> lists) {
    for (ArrayList<Integer> list : lists) {
        if (!list.contains(i)) {
            return false;
        }
    }
    return true;
}
```
<<<explanation>>>: The code first gets an iterator over the values of the HashMap (which are the ArrayLists). It then gets the first ArrayList and iterates over its elements. For each element, it checks if all other ArrayLists contain that element. If they do, it adds the element to the master list. The method allListsContain is a helper method that checks if all ArrayLists in a collection contain a certain element.

This solution has a time complexity of O(n*m) where n is the number of ArrayLists and m is the average size of the ArrayLists. This is because for each element in the first ArrayList, we are checking if it is contained in all other ArrayLists. The space complexity is O(m) because we are storing the elements of the first ArrayList in memory.

If you want to optimize the solution, you could sort the ArrayLists and use a two-pointer approach to find the common elements. This would reduce the time complexity to O(n*m*log(m)) and the space complexity to O(1). However, this would require modifying the ArrayLists and sorting them beforehand.

Please note that the time complexity of the solution can be improved by using a data structure like a Trie or a Binary Search Tree to store the numbers from the lists. This would allow for faster lookups and would reduce the time complexity to O(n*m*log(m)). However, this would require a significant amount of code and data structure knowledge.
